"We are also working closely with the government to ensure there is a uniform and consistent approach to addressing any issues raised. "It's clear a number of ways for students to have their mental health resolved through the university. "We are working closely with the University of Glasgow, and the University of Edinburgh and the local authorities to ensure they are able to deal with their own students' challenges. "The UK government have made it clear that we want to see students being treated with respect for their mental health and that we would be concerned to see more cases of people who are suffering from mental illness. "We would also hope that the Scottish Government would take appropriate action to ensure that the University of Edinburgh continues to be a safe place for all students to live and work."

Theresa May has said she is "honourably" supporting the UK government's move to create a duty of support for people suffering from mental health problems, but she remains critical of people who "have been given the wrong treatment".
